title: Will the U.S. Department of Justice approve AT&T's bid for Time Warner before 1 October 2017?
preds: Given the time and current status, and my objection to 0 and 100%

Usually, unless its a emergency, little of significance gets done in the Federal government on a Friday.  So I am going to assume this is NOT going to happen before weekend, and that means its going to finish as NO.
No, The Justice Department has not made trust busting a high priority this year.
Guess this isn't happening this week.
The Senate approved the appointment of Makan Delrahim to be the antitrust chief at the Justice Department by a vote of 73-31 late yesterday evening.
We are very nearly out of time for this question.  But I cannot go to zero because there is ironically a somewhat higher probability in these very last days before the end of the month.
Passage of time and no word of anything.
The clock has almost run out, and there's still no formal appointment for the head of DoJ's Antitrust Division.
Quick decission while North Korea is header no.1
There's only a week to go.
Money seems to be more influential now than in the past. Maybe we just know more. But favors or money will make this happen.
No final decision in the remaining 10 days for sure.
In such a short time there is little final outcome probable.
times running out, so much for a sure thing ;-)
Still on my countdown to zero with time running out. But ...
Following @Amazing-Criswell, but at a respectful distance.  Besides, I miss Gene Wilder.

Still radio silence from the DoJ, except for those rumors that they will approve by the end of this month.  Counting today, they have just eight days left to accomplish approval by the end of the month.  Still not seeing why they would approve without the new appointee in place.  But that assumption is definitely worthy of challenge, so I remain conflicted on this question.  What is tilting me to lower probability is that we are simply running out of time for this question, and there have been a series of unfulfilled predictions and leaks in the past.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
One of the highly controversial acquisitions in the US will not be completed while Trump's pick for DoJ's antitrust division is held back by the Senate since June.
rising slightly on some recent news re leaks from DOJ

The U.S. Department of Justice is in the final stages of its merger review, these people said." - http://www.latimes.com/business/hollywood/la-fi-ct-stankey-att-time-warner-culture-20170907-htmlstory.html
CEO was recently quoted as saying "by the end of the year", rather than "by the end of the month".

Aside from the obvious "lobbyists in Washington" argument, decisions in this administration have been markedly right-leaning. From the FCC to the President's own deregulatory agenda, the pro-business bent of the Trump appointees is hard to dismiss.

Unlikely. President Trump has been accused of profiteering. His administration will likely prevent a merger until sometime next year.
(This forecast is the product of perverse incentives. A more responsible forecast would be 20%.)
Because America loves monopolies. And the burecrats love under the table bonuses they get for these type of mergers.
Not by the end of October but probably by the end of the year.
Continuing my countdown to 0. DoJ has a lot on its plate right now. Hard to see this happening with less than four weeks remaining in September.

"advanced stage", but from other comments, this still seems like it might take this decision past the closing date.

Timeframe seems too short, too much is still to be done, especially politically.
Continuing my slow downward march to 0. Time is running out for this deal to be approved before 1 October, although I continue to expect that DoJ eventually will sign off on the merger.

I do not have any specific facts to add, just my analysis of those already presented.  Warren I see holding up the DoJ nominee and is obviously against  him and the merger.  Maybe she gives way some time in September.  Without him it's probably not going to happen by 10/1.   But even in Sept it is going to be tight.  I am going out on a limb and taking the under.

Downgrading, but still think its very possible for approval to be given within the next month, even without Delrahim. The noises are that the talks between AT&T and the DoJ are at an "advanced stage". https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-threatened-to-kill-the-at-t-time-warner-deal-but-its-very-much-alive-1502998077

There is an old expression about "running around like a chicken with its head cut off."  That is not the current situation in DoJ or most other federal agencies, including those headed by fixed-term appointees.  More like chickens whose heads were cut off about a week ago.  Nothing will happen, just as it has been with dizzying regularity for some time in most of the federal bureaucracy, until some adult leadership appears.  This is not imminent.

The DOJ needs an official leader! Without one, I don't see the approval happening before October 2017-maybe not before the end of 2017.

Except a few things, the might have prepared their legal stuff very seriously. This is a yes.
Trump will probably try to explain he doesn't want this, but will have to step back. As usual ....
The project is for Dec 2017 and will also probably be delated to February 2018.

The deal will probably go through by the end of the year, but seems rather stretched to be completed by the end of September.
It seems that Delrahim's confirmation will not happen before September at the earliest, not much time for the deal to be approved by the question's deadline.

Continuing my downward clock toward 0 because time is running out.

The lower echelons of DoJ have no clear guidance on anything except that the current administration wishes them to get to work prosecuting anti-Nazis and affirmative action programs, and putting away low-level drug users for life or longer.  The folks at those levels are none too enthusiastic about these priorities and, like skilled administrators everwhere, are adept at dragging their collective feet when they want to.  As a result, most of the department's processes could be outrun by a reasonably brisk glacier at the moment.  And that's before you get to Mr. Tangerine Man's spasmodic hostility to the players in this case, which also comes before any actual substantive concerns.  Putting the brakes on this one; probably come down some more fairly soon.

I think that the chaos of the Trump administration and the short timeframe go against the merger. Chances are high that it will actually happen, but not soon enough for this prediction. If the baseline is 70%, this is certainly over-optimistic. As each day goes by, the odds on the other side will continue to go up. It is difficult to go against the wisdom of the crowd, but I think we are much closer to 50%.
These things usually take longer than expected and this seems to have become a political football.

I divided this question into will they approve and if so, when.
Wisdom of the crowd was 70% so I used that as the baseline.
This in addition to the fact that the repuplicans is in power (which is more favorable to mergers) raises it by 10%. Donald trump lowers the odds by 5% however so it comes out at 75%
75% • the 95% of it being approved = 71.25%
taking into account the general trend so far and insecurity I will round it downward from 71.25 to 71
Nothing is getting done in TrumpLand
I think that this merger will go through, but I'm not convinced it'll be before Oct 1st.  I'll be watching this closely.
I hadn't heard about Warren delaying the antitrust nominee so I am dropping 30 points off my prediction and will probably keep going given how hard it is to get around a senate hold.
On a countdown to 0, due to timing.
will happen but not likely before October 1st
AT&T’s proposed $109bn bid for Time Warner will be a test of Trump's attitudes about anti-trust regulations.

Headlines today:	
AT&T's Time Warner Deal Looking Likely, Will It Be A Catalyst For The Stock?
Forbes
AT&T's proposed $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner is increasingly looking like a done deal. The acquisition is likely in the final stages of the

What I did you at this answer is I found the average of the two component probabilities of this question. Firstly, the probability of it being passed in general (regardless of timeframe), which I found to be .8. I think this because most evidence I found says that it has a strong chance, of approval, with few reasons it will not be. Next, the probability that it will be finalized by 1 Oct, 2017. I found this to be .4. I think this because most evidence suggests that there is a chance that it could be delayed, and is not in a rush. So, the average of .4 and .8 is .6.
Trump is against the deal and his pick for Assisstant Attorney General is not through Senate yet.
Seems AT&T thinks the merger is a done deal and the Justice department has started to draw up its rules for the merger.

The merger between Time Warner and AT&T is days away from being officially complete.  Both corporations are acting as if the deal has already been made.  A right hand man to AT&T CEO has been charged with running Time Warner's media business after the deal is fully complete.  The corporate restructuring was confirmed by AT&T.

The only legitimate reason for not approving would be concern about equal access by other media companies to ATT's network. This can be handled by imposing conditions on merger approval. Probability of political interference seems low given magnitude of Trump administration's other problems.

This seems likely considering the close relationship between DOD, telecommunications, and those appointed. 
It seems another justification to roll back net neutrality as well.

"The White House is closely monitoring the deal because Trump is worried about media concentration, according to one official. At the moment, Trump is leaving the review in the hands of the Justice Department, the official said."

Approval seems certain. Low forecast is for complications on the timeline.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-24/at-t-said-to-be-in-early-u-s-talks-for-time-warner-approval
1. DoJ anti-trust group starting discussions on vertical integration restrictions regarding competitors content access
2. DoJ anti-trust head is still waiting on Senate confirmation.
3. Suspicions that DTs interest in the media and dislike for CNN may provide opportunity to influence media coverage in return for less restrictive content agreements.

Dropping way down because the administration hasn't even nominated a person to handle approving the merger and the article below suggests that has put the process into a holding pattern.
They will probably approve it as they are pro-biz, but the timing might not be as fast as they would hope.
Almost certainly, President LIttlefingers would like to find a way to punish CNN in the course of this transaction.   He can't, of course, so it will go through reasonably smoothly.

DoJ staffers will carefully weigh the merits of the arguments and make a carefully reasoned recommendation, which will be followed if and only if it enriches the Prez, his posse, or the Attorney General.   Otherwise not.  Looks good for an okey-dokey.

Time Warner chief confident in approval of AT&T buyout
Speaking at Code Conference, Bewkes said “I don’t think who’s occupying the White House changes things ... We’re not particularly thinking that’s a significant fact. DOJ has a pretty clear set of precedents and laws to follow.”
https://seekingalpha.com/news/3271056-time-warner-chief-confident-approval-and-t-buyout

#1. Recent ISP privacy and Net Neutrality changes indicate strong anti-regulatory trend favoring communication giants. FCC already stating that they will not be reviewing the merger. (99%).
#2. Optics of the situation. US regulatory setbacks dished out within a few month period in the communication industry left a bitter taste in many members of the populace.  So for all campaigns aiming to stop the deregulation were unsuccessful. Public pressure against the merger might intensify seeing Time Warner and AT&T as the last stand against media giants. (-40%)
#3. Presidential self-proclaimed stance against Time Warner merger, but the effect of President Trumps dissent is hard to estimate, as is his actual position (-5%).
#4. It comes down to timing. Is the DOJ willing to review before October 1? I think not.  Not when there are national intelligence whistleblowers and Russian collaborators running amok.  (-5%)
Even though Donald Trump vowed to block it, it seems unlikely that this merger will not happen.  Whether it happens prior to the 1st of October will be the biggest question here.

I see it as likely, but there are significant hurdles that have not been considered by many. First, the DOJ still must finish the review process. Second, according to a Reuters article, a decision concerning the merger will not be considered until an Assistant Attorney General has been appointed to oversee the anti-trust division. Lastly, although Trump is pro-big-business, something has to be said about the campaign promise to block this acquisition in particular. Yes, I know that he has limited reach, but I would not put it past him to make deals, before appointing anyone, to at least postpone this merger.
I would like to think that this would be sooner and should be approved in 2018. Wheels of government move very slowly,
If you have been paying attention we are in a very Pro business environment.

I'm taking cosler's arguments below (thanks!) and aiming off because I think the timing might be an issue (so that it might eventually get approved, but it'll take longer due to the FCC wanting to dot all the i's in case POTUS calls then up).
Conventionally speaking,  this thing should be a green light - three reasons why it SHOULD go through:

They will not approve. There is too much pressure on other giant mergers and inversions to allow it. The "strong" man has to make one major point for the working man and this will be one of the only ones.

The DoJ will likely let this deal die on the vine. It's unclear if there are even staff in place to complete the review and approval of this transaction.

I believe this deal is likely to be approved because the people now overseeing the review have a friendlier view of free markets and distrust government interference. There are caveats because these reviews can take a long time and there is no guarantee the review will be completed by October. According to a Forbes article the average length of time for an intensive DOJ review is now 10 months and AT&T reported in early January that the DOJ started the process. I think this means the deal is approved before October but not much before.

FCC Review often takes 12-14 months, and Oct 1st would be less than 12 months from the merger date. Additionally, the odds of the merger being rejected or being delayed due to re-negotiations sway the odds towards no.

The FCC has pretty much cleared the merger. Trump is apparently against the deal (possibly because CNN is part of the package) but this is unsubstantiated. A precedent is Comcast's merger with NBC Universal, which was allowed to go ahead and where the industries of the respective companies were similar and it was also a vertical merger. If the issue is competition in streaming services then its a no-brainer that the deal goes ahead, the competition is growing all the time in that space with YouTube TV the latest entrant. Timeline could pose problems, but the first 30 day review was done in November, so once they get the documents from both companies, the DOJ should reach a preliminary decision in another 30 days, after which some possible adjustments to the terms might still have to be made.

The head of the U.S. Federal Communications Commission does not expect to review AT&T Inc's (T.N) planned $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner Inc (TWX.N), a spokesman for the agency said on Monday.

The current administration seems willing to deregulate some laws to help incentivize businesses to invest more in plants and equipments. The downside of deregulation sometimes leads to more concentrated markets and price hikes in the long run but, I think this merger will benefit consumers overall in terms of more TV options,data, and lower pricing.

CEO Randall Stephenson said earlier this month he expects the deal to be done by the end of the year.
Depends. Trump wants Time-Warner to rein in CNN and may punish it by seeing this does not go through. He may think better of it though because Big Business has its own ways to influence.

Upgrading my estimate. Shareholders have approved the merger, and Trump "reset" or softened some of his stances during the Sweden Incident Rally. If history is an indication, Trump will still complain, but will likely be overruled by more established administration officials. Sending Kushner to talk with Time Warner executives suggests CNN will be asked to soften it's coverage on Trump as a bribe for not siccing the DOJ on the merger. The trade-off could be as easy as cutting down on critics' air time, bringing in Trump confederates as opposed to surrogates. I think this is bordering on fairly unsupported conspiracy theory territory, but if Trump can install a favorable pundit onto CNN, and he can brag about said pundit in a tweet while still criticizing CNN, he will consider it a win and be convinced to let it go. Any situation where he gets retribution and can claim victory will be sufficient for DOJ to stay out of it.
Trump's image as the people's guy depends on this block.

DoJ will be more flexible given that Industry consolidation is Necessary for older line companies to stay competitive with new content providers like Netflix and amazon.

The most current news states that the merging companies expect the review to be completed in the year. Given that October 1 is substantially sooner than the end of year close predicted by the companies. A Bloomberg article (link: https://www.bna.com/atttime-warner-deal-n57982079076/) asserts that the DOJ may provide more evidence and review than is usual in vertical integration. An unsubstantiated rumor places President Trump against the merger. Senator Al Franken is also calling for a review. Given the statements (or rumored statement in Trump's case) these two powerful opponents may provide bi-partisan encouragement the DOJ to increase the DOJ review process. Until there are positive signs that the DOJ is opting for a speedy review process I opt to place a low to moderate probability of the deal being approved.

Similar to other mergers DOJ is ok with.  Is vertical integration.  https://www.wirelessweek.com/news/2017/01/all-eyes-doj-time-warner-deal-approval-following-trump-t-meeting

The Tweeter in Chief and his Whisperer have expressed opposition. Sen. Sessions will probably be confirmed as Attorney General despite the negative attention brought to his character by the Republican Senate's formal silencing of Sen. Warren. If DeVos could be confirmed, there's almost no way Sessions won't, as a more senior member of the Senate. Looking at precedent, Sessions will have to follow orders from Trump, or risk being fired as Sally Yates did, so if he's ordered to interfere with the merger, the Department Of Justice will likely attempt to block the merger.
